sentence.text: Fluvoxamine inhibits the CYP2C9 catalyzed biotransformation of tolbutamide.
In period A, all volunteers took 500 mg of tolbutamide orally.
Each group took either 150 mg or 75 mg of fluvoxamine a day for 5 days (day -3 to day 2).
The groups then took 500 mg of tolbutamide as a single dose (day 0).

RESULTS: During treatment with fluvoxamine, there was a statistically significant decrease in the median of the total clearance of tolbutamide, from 845 mL/h to 688 mL/h, among the volunteers who received 75 mg/d.
There was a reduction that reached borderline statistical significance in the group that received 150 mg/d of tolbutamide.

Thus there was a tendency toward a more pronounced inhibition of the 4-hydroxylation during treatment with 150 mg/d of fluvoxamine compared with 75 mg/d, but the difference was not statistically significant.
CONCLUSION: Fluvoxamine is a moderate inhibitor of CYP2C9 in vivo.
